questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following inhibits the rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis?
questions.explanation:
The rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis is tyrosine hydroxylase and is inhibited by 
metyrosine (alpha-methyl-p-tyrosine). Tyrosine hydroxylase converts tyrosine to dopa (rate-limiting step). Dopa is then converted to 
dopamine by dopa decarboxylase. Metyrosine is indicated preoperatively in pheochromocytoma and in inoperable cases. 100 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: An asthmatic patient has been taking a salbutamol inhaler to control his wheezing episodes. 
Which of the following is not an effect seen on stimulation of the receptor involved?
questions.explanation:
Salbutamol is a short-acting, selective 2-adrenergic receptor agonist used in the treatment of 
asthma and COPD. 2 receptors mediate the stimulation of lipolysis (not inhibition). Adrenergic control of adipose tissue: • Stimulation of lipolysis -  1, 1, 2, and 3 receptors • Inhibition of lipolysis -  2 Actions Adrenergic recept

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following statements most appropriately describes the vasomotor reversal of 
Dale?

options.a: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
options.b: Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
options.c: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by blockade of beta 2
options.d: Stimulation of beta 1 followed by blockade of beta 2

questions.explanation:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha ( 1) followed by stimulation of beta (2) 
receptors. Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces an  1-mediated rise in BP followed by a 
2-mediated fall in BP. Administration of epinephrine after administration of  -blockers produces only a fall in BP. This 
is because the  -mediated response is abolished and hence, only the -mediated response is seen, 
resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the vasomotor reversal of Dale. This was first 
demonstrated by Sir H.H.Dale.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following drugs when administered would lead to a biphasic reaction on blood 
pressure?
questions.explanation:
Biphasic reaction on blood pressure is seen with the administration of adrenaline. The BP initially 
rises followed by a fall in BP. Adrenaline acts on  1,  2, 1, 2, and 3 receptors.  1 - present in blood vessels - causes vasoconstriction - increases BP. 2 - present in blood vessels - causes vasodilatation - decreases BP. At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen. 
Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline. Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the 2 action 
predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen. This is referred to as the biphasic reaction. Adrenergic dr 
ug Receptors it acts on Adrenaline 
 1+  2+1+ 2+ weak 3acti 
on  1+ 2+1+ 3butno 2actio 
n Noradrenalin 
e 102 
Sold by @itachibot Adrenergic dr 
Receptors it acts on 
ug Isoprenaline 
1+ 2+ 3butno  action

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following would not increase with slow IV infusion of adrenaline?
questions.explanation:
Slow intravenous infusion of adrenaline results in a significant increase in systolic blood pressure 
with minimal effect on diastolic pressure. Mean blood pressure and pulse pressure increase. This is because of the increased systolic 
pressure coupled with decreased, unchanged, or an insignificant increase in diastolic pressure. At lower concentrations of adrenaline, vascular 2 receptors are more sensitive than  receptors, 
hence peripheral resistance decreases.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.a: IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
options.b: IV adrenaline increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
options.c: Dopamine increases peripheral resistance and improves renal perfusion
options.d: IV isoproterenol increases systolic and decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia

questions.explanation:
IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP but is unlikely to cause tachycardia. IV noradrenaline acts on  1,  2, and 1 receptors: •  1- vasoconstriction - Increases DBP. • 1 - increases heart rate and contractility - Increases SBP. • This increases mean arterial pressure which causes a reflex vagal activity that decreases the heart 
rate leading to bradycardia. IV adrenaline acts on  1,  2, 1, 2, and 3 receptors: • 1 - increases SBP, tachycardia. • DBP - either 2 - decrease DBP,  1 - increase DBP or  1+2 - no change. Dopamine acts on 1, 1, and D1 receptors: • D1 - low concentrations - causes vasodilatation thus improving renal perfusion • 1- positive inotropic effect - increases SBP. •  1 - higher infusion rates - causes vasoconstriction and increases peripheral resistance IV isoproterenol is a non-selective  receptor agonist: • 1- increases SBP • 2- vasodilatation - decreases DBP • 1- tachycardia

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient in low output cardiogenic shock is being treated with dobutamine. Which of the 
following is true about the drug?

options.b: Acts on D1 and D2 receptors
options.d: Has no effect on coronary circulation

questions.explanation:
103 
Sold by @itachibot Dobutamine decreases peripheral resistance minimally. Clinically, dobutamine increases cardiac output by selectively increasing myocardial contractility 
and promotes coronary vasodilation. This is associated with a mild decrease in total peripheral 
vascular resistance, which is mediated by the reflex withdrawal of sympathetic tone to the 
vasculature. Dobutamine has a t1/2 of 2 minutes. It resembles dopamine but no action is seen on dopamine 
receptors. Renal circulation is variably affected depending upon the sympathetic tone of the patient.

questions.question:
Question 8: During a rotation in the acute medical ward, you observe a patient in cardiogenic shock being 
started on a low-dose dopamine infusion. Which of the following would you expect to increase 
in this patient? 93 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
At lower doses (< 2 g/kg), dopamine only stimulates dopamine receptors in renal vasculature, 
causing increased urine output. As the dose increases (2-5 g/kg), additional cardiac stimulant action (1) is also seen. At very high doses (5-15 g/kg), vasoconstriction ( 1) is additionally seen.

questions.question:
Question 9: A stress ECHO has to be done for a 56-year-old COPD patient with high suspicion of coronary 
artery disease. Which of the following drugs can be used to perform this test?
questions.explanation:
Dobutamine is used to perform a stress test. Stress echocardiography is primarily done for the evaluation of myocardial ischemia. The basic 
principle is to increase cardiac stress (either with exercise or with a drug) in a controlled fashion, 
to aid with the identification and localization of ischemic areas (by detecting new or worsening 
wall motion abnormalities). Performing stress echocardiography with a pharmacologic agent such as dobutamine allows for 
simulation of increased heart rate and increased myocardial physiologic demands in patients who 
may be unable to exercise due to musculoskeletal or pulmonary comorbidities. Dobutamine causes cardiac stress by acting on 1-adrenergic receptors to increase cardiac 
contractility and heart rate, and on 2-adrenergic receptors to cause peripheral vasodilatation. It 
is preferred over vasodilators used in stress echo tests such as adenosine, dipyridamole, and 
regadenoson (adenosine derivative).

questions.question:
Question 10: You notice fenoldopam mentioned on the drug chart of an elderly male patient admitted in 
the ICU. What condition is he most likely being treated for?
questions.explanation:
Fenoldopam is primarily indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies. It is a D1 
agonist at peripheral D1 receptors and acts as a rapid-acting vasodilator. Drugs used in a hypertensive emergency are: • Nitroprusside • Nicardipine 104 
Sold by @itachibot • Labetalol • Hydralazine • Esmolol • Nitroglycerine • Phentolamine • Fenoldopam

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is not an indirectly acting sympathomimetic?
questions.explanation:
Oxymetazoline is a direct-acting non-selective  1 and  2 receptor agonist. Amphetamine, methamphetamine, and tyramine are catecholamine releasing agents and are 
considered to be indirectly acting sympathomimetic agents.

questions.question:
Question 12: 94 
Sold by @itachibot Following spinal anesthesia, the blood pressure of a patient started dropping. Your senior 
asks you to administer a mixed-acting sympathomimetic. Which of the following loaded 
syringes will you pick?
questions.explanation:
Ephedrine is a mixed-acting sympathomimetic agent which can be used to manage hypotension 
following spinal anesthesia. Drugs that release norepinephrine and also directly activate receptors are called mixed-acting 
sympathomimetics. Ephedrine has a dual action: • Releasing agent: releases neurotransmitters from nerve endings. • Direct action on  1,  2, 1, and 2 receptors. The adrenergic agents are classified into three sub-groups: • Directly acting agents: • Selective agents - phenylephrine ( 1), clonidine ( 2), dobutamine (1), terbutaline (2). • Non-selective agents - oxymetazoline ( 1 +  2), isoproterenol (1 + 2), epinephrine 
( 1 + 2 +1 + 2) norepinephrine ( 1 + 2 + 1) • Mixed acting agents - ephedrine ( 1 + 2 +1 + 2 + catecholamine releasing agent) • Indirectly acting agents: • Catecholamine releasing agents - amphetamine and tyramine • Uptake inhibitor - cocaine • MAO inhibitor - selegeline • COMT inhibitor - entacapone 105 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements is not true about clonidine?

options.a: It acts on alpha 2 adrenergic receptors
options.b: Can result in rebound hypertension on abrupt withdrawal

questions.explanation:
Clonidine is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. It is not associated with CNS stimulation. It treats high blood pressure by stimulating presynaptic  2 receptors in the vasomotor center in 
the brainstem. This binding has a sympatholytic effect, by suppressing the release of 
norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics. Option A - Clonidine is an alpha 2 receptor agonist that reduces central sympathetic outflow. Option B - Abrupt withdrawal after long-term therapy can result in rebound hypertension. Option D - Dry mouth and sedation are the major side effects of clonidine. It can also cause 
impotency and constipation.

questions.question:
Question 14: You are administering clonidine intravenously to a patient. Which of the following effects 
would you observe?

options.a: Prolonged rapid fall in blood pressure
options.b: Transient rise in blood pressure followed by a prolonged fall
options.c: Transient fall in blood pressure followed by a prolonged rise
options.d: Prolonged rapid rise in blood pressure

questions.explanation:
Intravenous administration of clonidine results in a transient rise in blood pressure followed by a 
prolonged fall.  2 receptors are present on the presynaptic as well as the postsynaptic ganglia. They are the 
autoreceptors of the sympathetic system. Clonidine is a directly acting  2 agonist. When it activates the postsynaptic  2 receptors in 
vascular smooth muscle, there is a transient rise in the blood pressure. This is followed by 
activation of central  2 receptors, which results in decreases the central sympathetic tone and 
causes a prolonged fall in blood pressure.  2 receptors are present postsynaptically in vascular walls and activation results in the same 
action as  1 stimulation i.e., vasoconstriction. But the major receptor that is responsible for 
vasoconstriction in vascular walls is the postsynaptic  1 receptor.

questions.question: Question 15: In which of the following patients is therapy with an adrenergic-agonist not useful?

options.a: 50-year-old woman suffering from acute decompensated heart failure
options.b: 35-year-old man in septic shock with persistent hypotension

questions.explanation:
Adrenergic agonists are not useful in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Adrenergic antagonists 
(phentolamine) are used locally for vasodilation in erectile dysfunction as PIPE therapy 
(Phentolamine Induced Penile Erection). Adrenergic agonists are mainly sympathomimetic due to their action on peripheral vascular or 
post-synaptic alpha receptors. However, certain adrenergic agonists (like clonidine) act as a 
sympatholytic due to their predominant action on pre-synaptic  2 receptors which inhibits the 
release of noradrenaline. Options A and B: In hypotensive states like shock and acute decompensated heart failure, 
short-term therapy with parenteral sympathomimetic drugs are indicated in treatment. Option C: Clonidine is an adrenergic agonist which acts on the pre-synaptic  2 receptor and 
is used in the treatment of hypertension. 106 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 22-week pregnant woman presents to the OPD for a routine check-up. On examination, her 
BP is 150/100 mmHg but she does not have a history of hypertension. You prescribe 
methyldopa to treat her. On which of the following receptors does this drug act?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario suggests a diagnosis of gestational hypertension, for which methyldopa is used. 
It acts on  2 receptors. Methyldopa is a centrally acting  2-adrenergic receptor agonist that is converted into 
alpha-methyl-norepinephrine. It decreases central sympathetic outflow, decreasing systemic 
vascular resistance without decreasing cardiac output.

questions.question:
Question 17: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug ‘X’. What would 
be the probable mechanism of action of drug ‘X’?
questions.explanation:
The probable mechanism of action of drug ‘X’ is 1 and 2 agonism. According to the given table, systolic BP and heart rate is increased due to 1 agonistic effect, and 
diastolic BP is decreased by vasodilatation due to 2 action. Option A: Action on  1 causes  DBP Option B: Action on M2 causes  HR and action on M3 causes vasodilatation and reflex increase 
in HR. Hence there is no net effect on heart rate Option C:  1 antagonism causes vasodilatation and  DBP. 2 action causes vasodilatation and 
DBP 




questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following is not an alpha adrenoreceptor agonist? 96 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Isoproterenol is a non-selective -receptor agonist with no action on  -receptors. Clonidine, guanabenz, and guanfacine are  2 receptor agonists.

questions.question: Question 19: Why is salbutamol preferred over adrenaline in the treatment of an asthmatic patient?
questions.explanation:
Salbutamol is preferred over adrenaline in an asthmatic patient due to 2 selectivity. This 2 selectivity is relative and lost at higher concentrations. Around 40% of the beta receptors 
are of 2 type and their activation won't cause cardiac stimulation. Major adverse effects of non-selective -agonists are attributed to the stimulation of 1 receptors 
in the heart which result in tachyarrhythmias. Selective 2 receptor agonists are introduced to 
overcome this major drawback.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 56-year-old man diagnosed with chronic bronchitis was prescribed a long-acting beta-2 
agonist. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
Formoterol is a long-acting 2 agonist (LABA). 2 agonists are classified as: 107 
Sold by @itachibot • Short-acting 2 receptor agonists (SABA): • Albuterol (Salbutamol) • Pirbuterol • Orciprenaline • Long-acting 2 agonists (LABA): • Salmeterol • Formoterol • Ultra-long acting 2 agonists (VLABA): • Indacaterol • Olodaterol • Vilanterol • Carmoterol

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following beta 2 receptor agonists was developed specifically as a uterine 
relaxant?
questions.explanation:
Ritodrine was developed specifically as a uterine relaxant. Salbutamol, orciprenaline, and terbutaline can also be used as uterine relaxants but were initially 
developed as inhalational agents for asthma. 2 agonists are associated with increased mortality 
and are rarely used as uterine relaxants now.

questions.question:
Question 22: 97 
Sold by @itachibot A child suffering from intermittent bronchial asthma is being treated with 2 agonists. Which 
of the following side effects would you not expect?
questions.explanation:
2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to 2 receptor-mediated 
glycogenolysis and glucagon release. Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists: • Hypokalemia - direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions • Tachycardia - reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on 2 receptors and direct 
effect on cardiac 1 receptors (2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) • Muscle tremors - direct effect on 2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia • Hyperglycaemia • Hyperlipidemia • Tolerance - desensitization on long-term use

questions.question:
Question 23: A 4-year-old child on salbutamol is brought to the hospital with complaints of tremors. Which 
of the following effects of the drug would explain this side effect?
questions.explanation:
108 
Sold by @itachibot Tremors due to 2 agonists can be both due to direct action on muscle spindle and hypokalemia. Initially, it was thought to be due to beta receptor-mediated enhancement of discharge of muscle 
spindles. However, recently the tremors have also been closely correlated with hypokalemia. 
Hence both direct action and hypokalemia can explain the tremors associated with 2 agonist use, 
although the exact mechanism is still not known.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.explanation:
Salbutamol in large doses can result in hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia. Option A: Tachycardia due to reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on 2 
receptors and direct effect on cardiac 1 receptors (2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) Option B: Tolerance occurs due to desensitization on long-term use Option C: Hypokalemia due to direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions

questions.question:
Question 25: A 68-year-old man with Parkinson's disease was prescribed mirabegron to control his 
symptoms of urinary urgency and incontinence. What is the mechanism of action of this 
drug?
questions.explanation:
Mirabegron is a 3 agonist used for the treatment of overactive bladder (OAB). Stimulation of 
3 receptors in detrusor muscle increases the bladder capacity and provides symptomatic relief in 
overactive bladder. Antimuscarinic drugs are the mainstay of oral pharmacological treatment for OAB. It acts by 
inhibiting muscarinic receptor subtypes, M2 and M3 in the bladder. Both subtypes are expressed 
in multiple tissues, resulting in anticholinergic adverse events such as dry mouth, constipation, 
and cognitive impairment. These adverse effects are not seen with mirabegron as it acts via 
adrenergic receptors. Mirabegron is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6. Hence, caution has to be exercised when 
prescribing it along with CYP2D6 substrates such as metoprolol, desipramine, digoxin.

questions.question: Question 26: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock?
questions.explanation:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of 
anaphylactic shock. For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and should be used 
very cautiously as slow bolus. There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage or 
misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred over 
intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk of 
cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias). For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1000 
dilution can be used. 109 
Sold by @itachibot In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use. The recommended 
dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of 1:10,000 solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutes 
during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines. Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to 
reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

questions.question:
Question 27: A patient was treated for septicemia with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following 
best explains the benefit of this drug?
questions.explanation:
The benefit of using noradrenaline in septicemia is that it increases the mean arterial blood 
pressure. It acts as a powerful peripheral vasoconstrictor and inotrope. Noradrenaline causes a rise in both systolic BP and diastolic BP, resulting in a rise in the mean 
arterial blood pressure. This increases the organ perfusion in patients in septic shock 
or cardiogenic shock. Another advantage of noradrenaline is that it does so without causing tachycardia, which is often 
a troublesome event with other inotropes in critical care. Options A and B: The rise in mean arterial pressure causes reflex bradycardia which is not a major 
contributor to the treatment of septic shock. Option C: Low-dose dopamine infusions and furosemide are used to increase urine output in 
critically ill patients.

questions.question: Question 28: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use:
questions.explanation:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml I.M. is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock. In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV route, and used 
cautiously. Adrenaline in a concentration of 1: 50,000 to 1: 200,000 is added to local anesthetics for: • Reducing the systemic absorption • Prolonging the duration of action • Providing a more bloodless field for surgery 1:1000 dilution can be used for the following routes of administration: • Intramuscular • Subcutaneous • Inhalational (nebulization) IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and 
safer (ie, lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular 
arrhythmias). There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by inappropriate dosage 
or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. 110 
Sold by @itachibot Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to 
reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics, to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD. Note: The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of a 1:10,000 solution administered 
IV every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines. For nebulization, 1:1000 
adrenaline is commonly used. 111 
Sold by @itachibot Parasympatholytics
